video.title: React / Typescript Tutorial - Build a Quiz App
video.description:
Learn how to use React and TypeScript to create a quiz app project. You will also learn how to use Styled-Components with React.

🔗 What you will make: https://tender-mcnulty-a4a646.netlify.app/
💻 Code: https://github.com/weibenfalk/react-quiz

🎥 Course from Thomas Weibenfalk. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/Weibenfalk

🔗 Thomas's website: https://www.weibenfalk.com/

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Faiyaz Rahman
topLevelComment.text:
I wish beginner friendly tutorials like this also taught better coding practices. There were so many times you said "this is a small app" or "there wont be performance issues at this scale" or "if YOU want to do some error handling you can do it here"

Where is the ownership, you're creating beginning content and writing lazy code like this would lead to new TS/JS devs adopting horrible practices.

topLevelComment.author: Marco Corapi
topLevelComment.text:
dangerouslysetinnerhtml - why it is necessary - Why not just pass:

{question}

or answer

{answer}

it was my understanding that babel in react would convert JSX into JS as well as HTML but maybe I am wrong. So the question is why using dangerouslysetinnerhtml to put directly HTML instead of JSX when we can do that normally? what is the point of or the differences?

replies.author: zc0rp10
replies.text: dangerouslysetinnerhtml is necessary becouse the questions and answers from the API are not just pure text in some cases, there's " and other such syntax in the reponse.

replies.author: Kalmar Lorand
replies.text: @Yosha Hi Yosha. You are right. Currently, I know React on a beginner to intermediate level and I started learning TypeScript.Can you recommend me any good tutorial videos which show actually good practice (what to use instead of React.FC, etc)? I'd really appreciate if you could help me as I can't find any good guides online except a few udemy courses and a few blogs which I can't verify whether they use good practice)

replies.author: Yosha
replies.text: And no useEffect for the API call. And using React.FC for components. And using enums over unions. I get that this is a beginner's tutorial but being beginner oriented isn't a free ticket to bad practice land.

topLevelComment.author: Martin
topLevelComment.text:
For those stuck as I was for a while with a TS error:
When he applies an OR to the Props using a 'Pipe', it looks like a slash. That's due to the confusing font.
Use a Single Pipe | to declare 'OR' in Typescript

topLevelComment.author: S Russo
topLevelComment.text: Informative and easy to follow. BUT, NOT SMART teaching beginners to use "Dangerously Set innerHTML".  Even if you say it's "ok" to use. What benefit is a beginner getting out of this? You're teaching beginners dangerous and bad habits that you have. No one mentions in the comments because they don't even realize. It'd be best to teach how to make a quiz app without putting high risk, and obscure things into an easy friendly teaching app. Cheapens the whole project and makes it useless. What's worst is you use it multiple times...

topLevelComment.author: damircast.
topLevelComment.text: I have a question at 35:59 Here you used an arrow function WITHOUT curly parenthesis { }, if I use them, I get 'undefined' for my answers-array at 38:32. Why does removing curly parenthesis shows the correct output?

replies.author: damircast.
replies.text: Got it! Without parenthesis, it's retuning always one statement, so the {} are not necessary because we have only one statement to return, but if we use the parenthesis, then we have to set a 'return' before

topLevelComment.author: Patrick C
topLevelComment.text: I think there is an error in the code.  In App.tsx, the only way to setGameOver is to click the Next button.  But by the logic that conditionally renders the Next button <number !== TOTAL_QUESTIONS - 1>, if you're on the last question, there is no Next button. So Technically, the game is never over.  After you answer the last question, the Start button renders because of userAnswers.length === TOTAL_QUESTIONS, but the game is still not over.

replies.author: Luigi Morel
replies.text: Using setInnerHTML in JavaScript puts your site at a risk of cross-site scripting. The React team came up with the dangerouslySetInnerHTML as a way of notifying you that what you are about to do is dangerous.

topLevelComment.author: Simon JOACHIM
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you very much for this video!

Does anyone know how to replace the trivia api by a local json file. I created one but I don't successfuly import it and make it works... When I try to replace the const endrpoint by my json file I obtain the following error: 
Uncaught (in promise) SyntaxError: Unexpected token < in JSON at position 0

Thank you in advance!

replies.author: Simon JOACHIM
replies.text: @Vedran B it's never too late ! Thank you very much for your well detailed answer !

replies.author: Vedran B
replies.text:
This might be a late answer, but in case anyone else wonders I'll reply. This type of error happens when it's actually an html file (that's why it's starting with "<") instead of json file. 
So to check that error, you would do this: in fetch process, when using 
fetch(APILink)
.then(res => res(text()) //so you can convert it to plain text
.then(text => console.log(text) //if you get results in console, it means that the structure of the file wasn't JSON, but HTML.

Why that would happen? HTML file might be returned from the server as a 404 (because the json file you requested is missing). Or your route might not be correct. Always go for checking what's going on with the console.log and rest of the developers tools, and you'll find a culprit real soon.

topLevelComment.author: JorgeVandS
topLevelComment.text:
I took this code and ran with it, now developing the app further so that I can put it in my portfolio.

Tip for those of you who want to let the user choose the category and difficulty: put the quiz logic that's in App.ts into its own component and then pass the state from a form component into that quiz component as props, then redeclare the props as constants within the quiz logic above where the url is fetched and enter those constants instead of the TOTAL_QUESTIONS and Difficulty.EASY ones. Finally, go into the API and pass those same values as props there, and then edit the URL so that it actually accepts a category too.

I'll link to my code if anyone's interested, just lemme know.

These changes make random quizzes impossible because of the customised URL, and that's something I'm now working on figuring out. Update if I do.

replies.author: igor thetigor

I tested during the development and it was highly conterintuitive (to me) to make an async function call from the APP component(async()=>await console.log(fetchcall())). the tutor wrapped it in async LATER. first it was console.log(fetchcall) ONLY which worked out only during first load of the page, after reload promise pending was received. that caused huge confusion for me. I ended up analyzing boilerplate of express-webpack-ts-react-babel to have a more solid setup and better understanding.

topLevelComment.author: Dan D
topLevelComment.text: Why use the dangerouslySetInnerHTML?  It effectively sets one up for cross site scripting allowing hackers to infect you.  Given this is more of a learning course, something like that shouldn't be in code since those learning will do it later and use it as a pattern with the work on other code, making the problem worse.  Nope should  do things the right way, especially in a training course...

replies.author: Dan D
replies.text: @Marco Corapi In a nutshell it should *ONLY* be used when you trust the source. Main reason is security.  Be very careful and not load scripts (oops html) from an un-trusted source(s), you may not be aware if your asking, an html element you load may have inline code, and that code will run with your credentials.   Reason it is used i'd assert the developer is lazy or doesn't know better.   Would guarantee you, if you working at a place with code reviews, would be surprised if you could check in code with a call to this function that is how bad it is.  Well unless you want a virus or three...

replies.author: Marco Corapi
replies.text:
exactly, I have doubts why it is used? why it is necessary. Why not just pass:

{question}

or answer

{answer}

it was my understanding that babel in react would convert JSX into JS as well as HTML but maybe I am wrong. So the question is why using dangerouslysetinnerhtml to put directly HTML instead of JSX when we can normally do that? what is the point of or the differences?

One tip:
When scaffolding the components. If you have emmet extension installed for React, you can type "rafce" and press tab and it will autocomplete.

replies.author: Andrey Babkin
replies.text: The extension is actually called "ES7+ React/Redux/React-Native snippets" not Emmet, and it can be installed from the market.  Emmet which is built-in to VS code by default doesn't support React snippets except for some very basic jsx syntax I believe.

replies.author: e leach

replies.author: Sergei Cherniaev
replies.text: If an API returns JSON with formatted HTML, without dangerouslySetInnerHTML it'll be escaped and you'll see HTML tags inside your p or span instead of formatted text.

topLevelComment.author: Aayush

replies.author: Vs Sm
replies.text: @Rand0mTV As I said, you just pretend. If you program anything at all you have to classify otherwise it's not programming, it's hardcoding.

replies.author: Rand0mTV
replies.text: @Vs Sm Well as anything in programming there is a use case for classes and there are situations where something else might be better suited for the job. Classes aren't the "silver bullet" for everything.

replies.author: Vs Sm
replies.text: @Rand0mTV In any case you work with classes and objects, you just pretend they are not.

replies.author: Vs Sm
replies.text: Only a few people actually get OOP concept, nothing surprising that others can't think classes.

replies.author: Rand0mTV
replies.text:
​@Aayush This really shouldn't depend on the team, but rather on the project and suggested practices. 
If you are working on a new project you should be using functional components since they are suggested and encouraged by the React team as far as I know.
If you are working on an existing project that has class based components then you should definitely know class based components so that you can maintain the project, but new components in that project should ideally be written as functional components.
If someone is more familiar with class based components and refuses to write functional components because of some reason they have, they shouldn't let their personal opinion affect the project and "drag it down" for no reason. If there's a good technical reason for it, then it's ok. But usually, great developers adapt to the needs of the project.
